responses: Hello! How can I help you start your open source journey today?
Hi there! Welcome to OpenSource Compass. Ready to contribute?
Hey! I'm here to guide you through the world of open source. What's on your mind?
I am the OpenSource Compass chatbot. I'm here to demystify open source and help you find your path to contributing.
OpenSource Compass is your guide to the open source world. We provide resources, tutorials, and project directories.
Open source software is code that is publicly accessible for anyone to view, modify, and distribute. It fosters collaboration.
In open source, the source code is made available for anyone to study, change, and improve. It's built by communities.
Start by finding a project you use or like. Look for 'good first issue' labels, fork the repository, and try to fix a small bug.
The best way to start is to read our 'Guides' section. It spans everything from picking a project to submitting your first PR.
Git is a distributed version control system. Essential commands: git init, add, commit, push, pull.
Git lets you manage code versions. Don't worry if it's confusing at first; everyone Googles git commands!
Run 'git init' to create a new Git repository in your current directory.
This command creates a hidden .git folder where Git stores all its tracking data.
Use 'git clone <url>' to download a repository to your local machine.
Cloning creates a local copy of the code so you can work on it.
'git status' shows you which files are staged, modified, or untracked. Run it often!
It's your best friend. It tells you exactly what state your working directory is in.
Use 'git add <filename>' to stage specific files, or 'git add .' to stage everything.
Staging prepares your changes to be committed. It's like putting a letter in an envelope before sealing it.
Stage your files first, then run 'git commit -m "Your message"'.
A commit is a snapshot of your code. Make your messages descriptive and imperative (e.g., 'Fix login bug').
Use 'git push origin <branch-name>' to upload your commits to the remote repository.
This updates the remote branch with your local commits. You might need to authenticate first.
'git pull' fetches changes from the remote and merges them into your current branch.
It's essentially 'git fetch' followed by 'git merge'. Run this before starting work to stay updated.
Use 'git branch <name>' to create one. Use 'git branch' to list them all.
Branches allow you to work on features in isolation. Always use a new branch for a feature or fix.
Use 'git checkout <branch-name>' to switch branches. Use 'git checkout -b <name>' to create and switch.
Note: Newer Git versions allow 'git switch <branch-name>' which is more intuitive.
Switch to the target branch (usually main) and run 'git merge <feature-branch>'.
This combines the history of the feature branch into the current branch.
'git stash' temporarily shelves your changes so you can switch branches without committing.
Use 'git stash pop' to bring those changes back later. Great for quick context switching.
'git cherry-pick <commit-hash>' applies the changes from a specific commit to your current branch.
Useful if you fixed a bug on the wrong branch and want to move just that fix.
Rebasing moves your branch to start from the latest commit of another branch. Keeps history linear.
Use 'git rebase main' on your feature branch to update it. careful: Don't rebase public branches!
'git reset --soft HEAD~1' undoes the commit but keeps changes staged. '--hard' deletes changes entirely (be careful!).
Useful for fixing the last commit or clearing your working directory.
'git revert <hash>' creates a *new* commit that undoes the changes of a previous one.
Safe for public history because it doesn't rewrite the past, just adds to it.
'git clean -fd' removes untracked files and directories. Useful to cleanup build artifacts.
Be careful: these files cannot be recovered via Git.
'git blame <file>' shows who last modified each line of a file and when.
Don't use it to shame! Use it to find who to ask questions to.
'git diff' shows changes between your working directory and the staging area.
'git diff --staged' shows changes you are about to commit.
'git fetch' downloads info about remote changes but doesn't merge them.
It's safe to run anytime. Follow it with 'git merge' or 'git rebase' when you're ready.
'git log' lists the commit history. Press 'q' to exit.
Try 'git log --oneline --graph --all' for a visual tree of your history.
Tags are used to mark specific points in history as important, usually for releases (v1.0).
Use 'git tag -a v1.0 -m "Release 1.0"' to create an annotated tag.
'git remote -v' lists all connected remote repositories.
'git remote add origin <url>' connects your local repo to GitHub.
It means you checked out a specific commit instead of a branch. If you make commits here, they can be lost easily. Create a branch to save them!
Submodules allow you to keep a Git repository as a subdirectory of another Git repository.
Git LFS (Large File Storage) replaces large files like audio/video with text pointers inside Git, storing the file contents elsewhere.
Issues are used to track bugs, enhancements, or tasks. Always search before creating a new one!
You can link PRs to issues using keywords like 'Fixes #123' in your PR description.
Push your branch, go to the GitHub repo, and you'll usually see a 'Compare & pull request' button.
Fill out the template! Explain what you did and why.
GitHub Projects lets you organize issues and PRs in Kanban-style boards.
Great for roadmap planning and tracking sprint progress.
Discussions are for open-ended conversations, Q&A, and ideas that aren't quite 'issues' yet.
It's like a forum built right into the repository.
GitHub Actions automates workflows (like testing, building, deploying) directly in your repo.
Workflows are defined in .github/workflows/*.yml files.
GitHub Pages hosts static websites directly from your repository for free.
Perfect for project documentation or personal portfolios.
Wikis provide a place for long-form documentation alongside your code.
They are actually separate Git repositories that you can clone and edit locally!
Releases are packaged versions of your software, based on Git tags.
They often contain changelogs and compiled binaries for users to download.
GitHub Sponsors allows the community to financially support the people who build the open source software they use.
You can sponsor individuals or organizations.
Forking creates a copy of the repo on your GitHub account. It's the standard way to contribute to projects you don't own.
You push changes to your fork, then open a Pull Request to the original (upstream) repo.
npm is the standard package manager for Node.js. 'npm install' downloads dependencies listed in package.json.
package.json is the manifest file for your project. Don't touch node_modules manually!
pip is the package installer for Python. 'pip install -r requirements.txt' installs dependencies.
Always use a virtual environment (venv) to isolate project dependencies!
Maven (pom.xml) and Gradle (build.gradle) are the main build tools for Java.
They handle dependencies, compilation, and packaging (JAR/WAR).
Cargo is Rust's package manager and build system. 'cargo build' compiles, 'cargo test' runs tests.
Dependencies are defined in Cargo.toml. Crates.io is the package registry.
Go Modules (go.mod) manage dependencies in Go. 'go get' adds a dependency.
Go emphasizes simplicity. Dependencies are downloaded directly from their source repos.
Bus Factor serves as a metaphor for the number of team members that would need to be hit by a bus (or leave) for the project to stall.
A low bus factor is risky. Documentation and shared knowledge increase it.
Bikeshedding happens when a team spends too much time debating trivial details (like the color of a bike shed) while ignoring complex issues.
Recognize it and move on!
Yak shaving is a series of small, seemingly unrelated tasks you have to perform before you can do the thing you actually want to do.
'I wanted to fix a bug, but first I had to update the OS, which required...'
A heated argument on the internet, often getting personal. Avoid them! Focus on technical merits.
If a thread gets toxic, disengage. Maintainers may lock the conversation.
BDFL (Benevolent Dictator For Life) refers to a leader who has final say in disputes (e.g., Linus Torvalds for Linux).
It's a common governance model, contrasting with consensus-based models.
Permissive. Do whatever you want, just keep the copyright notice.
Permissive, but protects you from patent trolling. Used by Google, Android, Kubernetes.
Copyleft. Changes must be open sourced under the same license.
Like GPL, but closes the 'SaaS loophole'. If you run it on a server for users, you must share changes.
Very similar to MIT. The '3-clause' version prohibits using the author's name for endorsement.
Dedicating the work to the public domain. No restrictions at all.
Usually for content (images, text), not code. CC-BY requires attribution. CC-BY-SA is copyleft for content.
Linting analyzes code for potential errors and stylistic issues without running it.
Always lint before pushing! It saves time in code review.
Code coverage measures how much of your code is executed by tests. Aim for high coverage!
Unit tests check small parts; integration tests check how they work together.
CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) is a list of publicly disclosed security flaws.
Keep your dependencies updated to avoid known CVEs.
Never report security bugs in public issues! Check the SECURITY.md file for an email address.
This is called 'responsible disclosure'—giving maintainers time to fix it before hackers find it.
Google Summer of Code (GSoC) is a global program that offers stipends to contributors for working on open source projects.
It happens every summer (May-August). You need to write a proposal for a participating organization.
Social Summer of Code (SSOC) is a 10-week open-source program designed for beginners to get started with contribution.
It usually runs in the summer and offers swags and certificates.
Social Winter of Code (SWOC) is an open-source program that runs in winters (Jan-Mar), aimed at introducing students to open source.
It's a great alternative if you missed summer programs! Beginners are very welcome.
GirlScript Summer of Code (GSSoC) is a 3-month long open source program. Whether you are a beginner or an expert, GSSoC is open to everyone.
It's famous for being extremely beginner-friendly and having a vast number of projects.
Outreachy provides paid, remote internships for people subject to systemic bias and those from underrepresented groups in tech.
It runs twice a year (May-Aug and Dec-Mar). The application process involves an initial eligibility check and a contribution period.
The MLH Fellowship is a 12-week internship alternative where you contribute to major open source projects like React, Meta, etc.
It's very competitive and simulates a real-world software engineering environment.
LFX Mentorship (formerly CommunityBridge) offers paid mentorships for working on Linux Foundation projects (Kubernetes, CNCF, etc.).
It runs year-round in different terms (Spring, Summer, Fall).
Hacktoberfest requires 4 valid Pull Requests to opted-in repositories during October.
Always check for the 'hacktoberfest' topic on the repo. Spammy PRs will get you disqualified!
You must be at least 18 years old and eligible to work in your country of residence. You don't need to be a student anymore!
GSoC usually announces orgs in Feb. Contributor proposals are due in April. Coding happens May-August. Results in September.
Stipends vary by country (PPP based). It can range from $1500 to $3000+. It's paid in two installments (mid-term and final).
SSOC is open to everyone! There are no age restrictions or specific qualifications. Beginners are highly encouraged.
SSOC typically runs from June to August. Registration usually starts in May.
Participants can win T-shirts, stickers, badges, and certificates based on the points they earn on the leaderboard.
SWOC is open to all students and professionals. No prerequisites required, just a zeal to learn!
SWOC is a winter program. Registrations: Dec. Coding: Jan-Feb. Results: March.
Top contributors get cool swag kits (T-shirts, stickers), certificates, and sometimes internship opportunities with partner companies.
Despite the name 'GirlScript', GSSoC is open to ALL genders and nationalities. Everyone can participate!
GSSoC is a 3-month program, usually running from May to August. Registrations open around Feb-March.

patterns: what do i get from gssoc
responses: Certificate of Appreciation, Top performers get Swag kits, and internship opportunities with hiring partners.
You must be available for full-time internship work. Open to women (cis/trans), trans men, non-binary people, and all underrepresented groups in tech.
Yes! Outreachy interns are paid a stipend of $7,000 USD for the 3-month internship.
Rounds happen twice a year. May-Aug round (apply in Jan/Feb). Dec-Mar round (apply in Aug/Sep).
Open to students and recent graduates who know how to code. You must be able to commit 30 hours/week.
They have three tracks: 'Open Source' (contribute to big projects), 'Software Engineering' (work on partner projects), and 'Web3'.
It is a scholarship program. They provide a diverse educational stipend based on need and location, significantly covering living costs.
Eligibility varies by project, but generally open to anyone who is not currently a maintainer of the project they are applying to.
Yes, LFX mentorships are paid! Stipends are adjusted based on your location and can be around $3000-$6000 USD.
A pull request (PR) is a way to propose changes to a repository. Fork the repo, create a branch, make changes, commit them, and push to your fork, then open a PR on GitHub.
Pull requests allow maintainers to review your code before merging it. They're the standard way to contribute to open source projects.
Steps: 1) Fork the repo 2) Clone to your machine 3) Create a branch 4) Make your changes 5) Push to your fork 6) Open a PR with a clear description.
Forking creates a personal copy of someone else's repository under your GitHub account. You can then make changes without affecting the original project.
Click the 'Fork' button on GitHub's repository page. This creates a copy you own, allowing you to freely experiment.
A code of conduct is a set of rules and guidelines that define acceptable behavior in a community. Always read the project's code of conduct before contributing.
Most open source projects have a CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md file. It promotes inclusivity and respect among contributors.
Use the project's issue tracker (usually GitHub Issues) to report bugs, suggest features, or ask questions. Before creating an issue, check if a similar one already exists.
A good issue includes: a clear title, detailed description, steps to reproduce (for bugs), and your environment details.
Write clear, concise commit messages in imperative mood (e.g., 'Add feature' not 'Added feature'). Include what and why, not just what changed.
Example: 'Fix login timeout issue by increasing session duration' is better than 'Fix bug'. Conventional Commits format is becoming standard: type(scope): description.
Typical workflow: 1) Find an open issue 2) Express interest in the issue 3) Create a branch and work on the fix 4) Submit a PR 5) Respond to reviews 6) Get merged!
Always communicate with maintainers. Some projects require issue assignment before you start coding.
Code reviews help maintain quality. Be open to feedback—it's not personal criticism, it's improvement for the project.
When you get review comments: 1) Read carefully 2) Discuss if you disagree 3) Make requested changes 4) Push updates 5) Reply to comments.
Documentation contributions are valuable! Fix typos, improve clarity, add examples, or write tutorials. Many projects welcome documentation PRs.
Start by improving the README, fixing typos, or adding examples. Good documentation is often overlooked but hugely appreciated.
Look for issues labeled 'good first issue', 'beginner-friendly', or 'help wanted'. These are specifically curated for newcomers.
Don't worry if you can't code yet! Many projects need help with documentation, testing, design, or bug reports.
Popular licenses: MIT (permissive), Apache 2.0 (permissive with patent clause), GPL (copyleft), BSD (similar to MIT). Choose based on your needs.
Visit choosealicense.com for help picking a license. Most beginner projects use MIT or Apache 2.0.
Be respectful, patient, and kind. Read the CONTRIBUTING.md file. Ask questions if unsure, and thank people for their help.
Remember: maintainers are often volunteers. Be understanding if responses are slow, and never demand features or priority.
Tests ensure code quality and prevent regressions. Contributing tests is a great way to help! Most projects have testing guidelines in their docs.
If a project lacks tests, writing tests for bugs or new features can be a valuable contribution.
You're testing the limits of my knowledge! Try asking about git commands, pull requests, licenses, or community terms.
I might not know that one yet. Ask me about 'forking', 'npm', 'code of conduct', or 'conventional commits'!
Not sure about that. Check the project's documentation or ask on their discussion board. Maintainers are usually helpful!
'git bisect' uses binary search to find the commit that introduced a bug. It's magical for debugging regressions.
You mark a 'good' commit and a 'bad' one, and Git helps you narrow it down.
'git reflog' shows a log of all updates to the tip of branches. It saves you when you accidentally delete something!
Even if a commit isn't in 'git log', it might be in 'git reflog'.
'git worktree' lets you check out more than one branch at a time in separate folders from the same repo.
Great for fixing a hot bug on main whilst in the middle of a huge feature on another branch.
'upstream' usually refers to the original repository you forked from. 'origin' is your fork.
You pull from upstream to stay updated, and push to origin to submit PRs.
Semantic Versioning (SemVer) uses MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH (e.g., 1.2.3).
MAJOR = breaking changes, MINOR = new features (compatible), PATCH = bug fixes.
A CLA (Contributor License Agreement) creates a legal contract between you and the project maintainers.
DCO (Developer Certificate of Origin) is simpler—you just add 'Signed-off-by' to your commits.
Imposter syndrome is huge in tech! Even senior engineers feel it. You are learning, and that's enough.
Don't compare your behind-the-scenes with everyone else's highlight reel. You belong here.
Open source burnout is real. It's okay to take a break. Your health is more important than a GitHub streak.
communicate with maintainers if you need to step back. They will understand.
Create a repo with your username (e.g., username/username) to add a README to your GitHub profile!
It's a great place to show off your tech stack and stats.
Docker packages applications into containers so they run the same everywhere.
A Dockerfile defines the image, and docker-compose runs multi-container apps.
TypeScript is JavaScript with syntax for types. It helps catch errors early and makes code more maintainable.
Kotlin is a modern, concise language heavily used for Android development. It is 100% interoperable with Java.
Swift is Apple's powerful and intuitive programming language for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS.
PHP is a popular general-purpose scripting language that is especially suited to web development.
Ruby is a dynamic, open source programming language with a focus on simplicity and productivity.
C# is a modern, object-oriented, and type-safe programming language. It enables developers to build many types of secure and robust applications that run in .NET.
C is a general-purpose, procedural computer programming language supporting structured programming, lexical variable scope, and recursion. It's the basis of extensive legacy infrastructure.
R is a programming language for statistical computing and graphics. It is widely used among statisticians and data miners.
MATLAB is a proprietary multi-paradigm programming language and numeric computing environment developed by MathWorks.
Scala combines object-oriented and functional programming in one high-level language. It runs on the JVM.
Perl is a family of two high-level, general-purpose, interpreted, dynamic programming languages. 'There is more than one way to do it'.
Lua is a lightweight, high-level, multi-paradigm programming language designed primarily for embedded use in applications (like games!).
Dart is a client-optimized language for fast apps on any platform. It is the language used by Flutter.
Haskell is a widely used purely functional language. It is known for its strong static typing and lazy evaluation.
Elixir is a dynamic, functional language designed for building scalable and maintainable applications. It runs on the Erlang VM.

Clojure is a dynamic, general-purpose programming language, combining the approachability and interactive development of a scripting language with an efficient and robust infrastructure for multithreaded programming.
Julia is a high-level, high-performance, dynamic programming language. It is well suited for numerical analysis and computational science.
VBA (Visual Basic for Applications) is the programming language of Excel and other Office programs.
Objective-C is the primary programming language you use when writing software for OS X and iOS. It's strictly a superset of C.
Assembly language is a low-level programming language for a computer or other programmable device specific to a particular computer architecture.
React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It is maintained by Meta and a community of developers.
Vue.js is a progressive JavaScript framework for building user interfaces. It is designed to be incrementally adoptable.
Angular is a platform for building mobile and desktop web applications. It is a complete rewrite of the same team that built AngularJS.
Svelte is a radical new approach to building user interfaces. It shifts that work into a compile step that happens when you build your app.
Next.js gives you the best developer experience with all the features you need for production: hybrid static & server rendering, TypeScript support, smart bundling, route pre-fetching, and more.
Nuxt is an open source framework that makes web development intuitive and powerful. Create performant and production-grade full-stack web apps and websites with confidence.
Gatsby is a React-based open source framework with performance, scalability and security built-in.
Django is a high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design.
Flask is a micro web framework written in Python. It is classified as a microframework because it does not require particular tools or libraries.
FastAPI is a modern, fast (high-performance), web framework for building APIs with Python 3.6+ based on standard Python type hints.
Spring Boot makes it easy to create stand-alone, production-grade Spring based Applications that you can 'just run'.
Laravel is a web application framework with expressive, elegant syntax.
Ruby on Rails is a web-application framework that includes everything needed to create database-backed web applications according to the Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern.
Express is a minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework that provides a robust set of features for web and mobile applications.
Nest (NestJS) is a framework for building efficient, scalable Node.js server-side applications.
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a domain-specific language used in programming and designed for managing data held in a relational database management system.
NoSQL databases are non-tabular, and store data differently than relational tables. They come in a variety of types based on their data model.
PostgreSQL is a powerful, open source object-relational database system with over 30 years of active development.
MySQL is the world's most popular open source relational database management system.
MongoDB is a source-available cross-platform document-oriented database program. Classified as a NoSQL database program, MongoDB uses JSON-like documents with optional schemas.
Redis is an open source (BSD licensed), in-memory data structure store, used as a database, cache, and message broker.
SQLite is a C-language library that implements a small, fast, self-contained, high-reliability, full-featured, SQL database engine.
Apache Cassandra is a free and open-source, distributed, wide-column store, NoSQL database management system designed to handle large amounts of data across many commodity servers.
Firebase is a platform developed by Google for creating mobile and web applications. It includes a real-time database and authentication services.
Supabase is an open source Firebase alternative. Build in a weekend, scale to millions.
Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a subsidiary of Amazon providing on-demand cloud computing platforms and APIs.
Microsoft Azure is a cloud computing service created by Microsoft for building, testing, deploying, and managing applications and services.
Google Cloud Platform (GCP), offered by Google, is a suite of cloud computing services that runs on the same infrastructure that Google uses internally.
Kubernetes is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
Jenkins is a free and open source automation server. It helps orchestrate the different parts of the software development process.
Heroku is a platform as a service (PaaS) that enables developers to build, run, and operate applications entirely in the cloud.
Vercel is a platform for frontend frameworks and static sites, built to integrate with your headless content, commerce, or database.
Netlify is a cloud computing company that offers hosting and serverless backend services for web applications and static websites.
DigitalOcean is an American cloud infrastructure provider headquartered in New York City with data centers worldwide.
Nginx is a web server that can also be used as a reverse proxy, load balancer, mail proxy and HTTP cache.
The Apache HTTP Server is a free and open-source cross-platform web server software.
Visual Studio Code is a source-code editor made by Microsoft for Windows, Linux and macOS.
IntelliJ IDEA is an integrated development environment (IDE) written in Java for developing computer software.
Postman is an API platform for building and using APIs.
Figma is a collaborative interface design tool.
REST (Representational State Transfer) is a software architectural style that defines a set of constraints to be used for creating Web services.
GraphQL is a query language for your API, and a server-side runtime for executing queries by using a type system you define for your data.
Microservices are an architectural style that structures an application as a collection of services that are highly maintainable and testable.
Agile software development creates software through the collaborative effort of self-organizing and cross-functional teams and their customer/end user.
Test-driven development (TDD) is a software development process relying on software requirements being converted to test cases before software is fully developed.
CI/CD bridges the gaps between development and operation activities and teams by enforcing automation in building, testing and deployment of applications.
Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code.
FOSS stands for Free and Open Source Software. FLOSS adds 'Libre' to emphasize freedom.
Copyleft is the practice of granting the right to freely distribute and modify intellectual property with the requirement that the same rights be preserved in derivative works.

The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) is an online community that produces freely-available articles, methodologies, documentation, tools, and technologies in the field of web application security.
Cross-site scripting (XSS) is a type of security vulnerability typically found in web applications. XSS attacks enable attackers to inject client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users.
SQL injection is a code injection technique, used to attack data-driven applications, in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field for execution.
